abstractText: Abstract: This work resolves a longstanding tension between the physically-expected stability of the microcanonical ensemble for gravitating systems and the fact that the known negative mode of the asymptotically flat Schwarzschild black hole decays too rapidly at infinity to affect the ADM energy boundary term at infinity. The key to our study is that we fix an appropriate off-shell notion of energy, which we obtain by constructing the microcanonical partition function as an integral transform of the canonical partition function. After applying the rule-of-thumb for Wick rotations from our recent companion paper to deal with the conformal mode problem of Euclidean gravity, we find a positive definite action for linear perturbations about any Euclidean Schwarzchild (-AdS) black hole. Most of our work is done in a cavity with reflecting boundary conditions, but the cavity wall can be removed by taking an appropriate limit.

1 Introduction
sections.text:
The study of black hole thermodynamics via Euclidean path integrals dates from the seminal work [1] of Gibbons and Hawking in the 1970’s. The associated technology for studying the canonical ensemble and analyzing stability is by now well-developed [1–10] and has been applied to a vast range of systems and partition functions (see e.g. [11–15] for recent examples). In contrast, Euclidean path integral treatments of the microcanonical ensemble have received relatively little attention. References discussing “microcanonical” path integrals and their saddle-points include [14, 16–18], but these references differ among themselves in their choices of boundary condition and/or partition function to compute. Furthermore, the only reference we have found addressing stability of saddle points for microcanonical path integrals in Einstein-Hilbert gravity is [3], which appears to claim that Euclidean Schwarzschild with zero cosmological constant is an unstable saddle in a reflecting cavity of any size. Since Schwarzschild is known to be a local maximum of bifurcation-surface area under fixed-energy on-shell perturbations,1 such a result would be in strong tension with the interpretation of black holes as thermodynamic systems with entropy SBH “ A4G .
1For zero cosmological constant this local maximum follows in particular from the classic analyses [19, 20] of dynamical stability of Schwarzschild and the fact [21] that such stability is equivalent positivity of the canonical 2nd order energy E “ δ2M ´ κ8πGδ 2A´ ř A ΩAδ 2JA with respect to perturbations that preserve the energy at first order (since the canonical energy turns out to depend only on the first-order part of the perturbation and since Schwarzschild has ΩA “ 0).
– 1 –
J H E P 1 1 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 0 4 6
In fact, the tension goes rather deeper. While the Euclidean asymptotically flat Schwarzschild black hole is a saddle for the canonical-ensemble path integral, in that context it has a negative mode that vanishes rapidly at infinity. As a result, the negative mode does not affect the boundary term that computes the asymptotically-flat ADM energy, and fixing this boundary term cannot remove the negative mode. For fixed black hole mass M , the negative mode should thus again persist in a large enough cavity or in an asymptotically AdS space of sufficiently large AdS scale `. Though we have not found explicit discussion of this point in published works, we believe it to be the reason for the dearth of literature on microcanonical stability in gravitational systems. We resolve this apparent contradiction below by following the approach to microcanonical gravitational path integrals described in [14] (see also related comments in [18]). This approach builds on the success of the standard path integral for the canonical partition function
Zpβq “ ż DgR,βe´Irgs (1.1)
in a cavity of radius R. In particular, it does so by defining the microcanonical partition function ZmicropEq as an integral of Zpβq over an appropriate contour Γ in the complex β-plane; i.e.
ZmicropEq “ ż

Here FEpβq is a weighting function and DgR,β denotes an appropriate measure on the space of metrics with boundary Sn ˆ S1 in which the Sn has radius R and the S1 has proper length2 β. As described in [14], with an appropriate FEpβq classical solutions with energy E will provide saddle points for the path integral (1.2). The details of Γ and FEpβq will be specified below. The starting point for the current work is the observation that one can perform the integral over β in (1.2) before evaluating the integral over gβ,R. The result is a microcanonical path integral that fixes a certain off-shell notion of gravitational energy which includes non-trivial contributions from degrees of freedom that violate the gravitational constraints. As a result, our energy is not just a boundary term at the cavity wall. The details of this notion of energy depend on which aspects of the metric are held fixed when integrating over β, but for a simple choice and for static fluctuations it becomes essentially the standard off-shell Hamiltonian associated with translations along the bulk Killing field. In addition, for linear static fluctuations about AdS-Schwarzschild it becomes equivalent to 1{4G times the area A of the extremal surface at the Euclidean horizon. We analyze this choice in detail and, using the rule-of-thumb from [22] for Wick rotations to deal with the conformal mode problem of the Euclidean path integral, we find the microcanonical Euclidean action at quadratic order to be positive definite. Thus, as expected, all Euclidean (AdS) Schwarzschild black holes provides stable saddles for our
2Since we will generally work in a finite cavity, it is natural to parameterize the size of the S1 using proper distance and to parameterize the size of the Sn using the area-radius. It is straightforward to rescale by an appropriate function of R in order to, for example, instead use a notion of distance defined by a boundary metric in some conformal frame when taking the RÑ8 limit in asymptotically AdS spacetimes.

J H E P 1 1 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 0 4 6
microcanonical path integral. This provides an important check on the admittedly-formal reasoning we use to derive our microcanonical path integral. We begin by describing the general construction of our microcanonical path integral in section 2. This involves specifying the details of the various ingredients that compose (1.2), performing the integral over β, and determining the appropriate off-shell notion of energy that becomes fixed. As stated above, with simple choices and for static linearized fluctuations about AdS-Schwazschild saddles this off-shell energy becomes the area of the extremal surface at the Euclidean horizon, though we also discuss 2nd order contributions. We then describe the strategy to be used to investigate saddles of the resulting path integral in section 3. The actual analysis of stability then begins in section 4, which considers Euclidean AdSd-Schwarzschild black holes in a cavity for d “ 4, 5 and describes details of their perturbations. Stability results are presented in section 5. As indicated above, the numerical results show these solutions to define stable saddles of our microcanonical path integral. The case of vanishing cosmological constant is included as a natural limit. We conclude with a summary and discussion of open questions in section 6.

sections.heading: 2 Microcanonical path integrals and their fluctuations
sections.text:
Let us consider the canonical path integral (1.1) computing the partition function Zpβq for a gravitating system with Euclidean boundary Sn ˆ S1. We take the S1 (which we think of as Euclidean time) to have proper length β and we take the sphere Sn to have area-radius R. Thus we choose to work in a finite cavity. This choice plays little role in the present section, and indeed it is trivial to take RÑ8. While it is far from clear that the finite R setting can define a consistent theory at the microscopic level (see e.g. [23–25]), we make this choice here for consistency with later sections where the finite cavity provides a useful infrared (IR) regulator for numerical calculations. In particular, it renders the spectrum of appropriate differential operators discrete. As mentioned in the introduction, we will follow the approach to the microcanonical path integral described in [14]. To explain the idea, recall that one expects the canonical path integral (1.1) to in some sense compute a statistical sum zpβq :“ ř
E e ´βE , where
the sum is over all energy levels E of the gravitational system. Analytically continuing β Ñ β ` iT with β, T real, choosing an arbitrary reference value β0, and introducing the weighting function fE0pT q, we may consider the integral

Note that this is of much the same form as (1.2) with fE0pT q “ FE0pβ0 ` iT q and Γ given for all E by the contour Re β “ β0. We see that the result is a microcanonial statistical model associated with the Fourier-transformed weighting function rfE0pEq (where we have made an appropriate choice of normalization for the Fourier transform). It is then natural to choose rfE0pEq to be real and to be concentrated in a small window ∆E near E0, in

Ref. [14] took rfE0 to be a Gaussian centered at E0 and studied the limit where the width σ of this Gaussian was small. We will do the same here, choosing
fE0pT q “ e´iE0T e´σ 2T 2{2G “ e´ie0T {Ge´σ2T 2{2G, (2.4)
where we take E0 “ e0{G with e0 and σ2 independent of the Newton constant G so that all dependence on G is explicit on the right-hand side of (2.4). In the limit of strictly-vanishing σ this construction is equivalent to performing an inverse Laplace transform of the canonical partition function Zpβq. Saddle points for the resulting path integral were discussed in [14]. We wish to extend the discussion of [14] to consider off-shell fluctuations about such saddles. One approach would be to perform all integrals simultaneously using the saddlepoint approximation and to study fluctuations that allow changes in both T and gR,β0`iT . Recall, however, that has been useful in the past to formulate the stability problem in terms of a Sturm-Liouville-type eigenvalue problem. In particular, this is the setting required to apply the rule-of-thumb from [22] to specify a contour of integration for the path integral. However, this will not be the case if we study all fluctuations together as the T variable adds a degree of freedom, effectively removing one of the two boundary conditions that one would expect. We will thus perform the integral over T before integrating over metrics with fixed T . This allows us to write the result as a path integral over metrics which, in the limit σ Ñ 0 and for time-independent metrics, can be described as having fixed value of a off-shell energy that we call H. The stability problem can then be formulated in a more familiar way. In order to implement the above procedure, we must first introduce an additional structure on the space of metrics that defines what is meant by ‘metrics with fixed T ’. While it seems likely that any such choice will break diffeomorphism-invariance, it also seems likely that the physics will independent of how we divide the integral over metrics into an integral over T and integrals over ‘metrics with constant T .’ The second expectation follows from the observation that, at least on the surface, changing this choice just corresponds to performing the required integrals in a different order. On the other hand, we also note that the microcanonical path integral (2.3) integrates over a contour on which metrics cannot be real, and that specifying precisely what is meant by allowing the period β “ β0 ` iT to be complex ‘without deforming the contour for the other variables of integration variables’ requires us to make some such choice. Thus the expectation that predictions of the ensemble will not depend on this choice relies on assuming that the contour can be deformed without
– 4 –
J H E P 1 1 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 0 4 6
changing the partition function. While this seems entirely plausible, we will not investigate it further in this work. Instead, we simply make a particular choice below and leave further exploration of this issue for the future. Our choice is explained and discussed in section 2.1 below. We also henceforth restrict consideration to time-independent metrics. In particular, though we will continue to use the same notation DgR,β for the functional integral, this symbol should henceforth be understood to be a measure on the space of time-independent metrics. We hope to provide a more complete treatment in future work by using the Hamiltonian formalism. Section 2.2 will then describe properties of the saddles and fluctations about saddles in the microcanonical ensemble that will finally allow us to formulate microcanonical stability as a Sturm-Liouville-type problem in section 3.

As noted above, our approach requires us to introduce a new structure on the space of (time-independent) metrics in order to define what is meant by ‘metrics with fixed T ’, or equivalently with fixed (complex) β. Specifically, let us consider the space GR of (timeindependent) metrics which induce boundary metrics S1 ˆ Sd´2 on the cavity walls. We take this to be a metric product so that the S1 is orthogonal to the Sd´2 and the latter is a round sphere. The subscript R indicates the radius of the Sd´2 but the proper length of the S1 factor is not constrained. As depicted in figure 1 below, we will define a map Ψβ̂ on GR such that, for each metric g P GR, the result Ψβ̂pgq will have Euclidean period β̂. We will then say that two metrics g1, g2 are ‘the same up to a change of β’ if g1Ψβ̂pg2q for some value of β̂. Our choice will be specified by using a set of coordinates τ, xi with τ singled out as describing (Euclidean) time. For all spacetimes we take τ to be periodic with period 2π. For simplicity, we will in fact choose coordinates so that the induced metric on the cavity wall takes the form

Moreover, the β appearing in eq. (2.5), which we will call the period of the S1, is independent of xi, τ . Furthermore, there will be some codimension-2 surface γ at which the τ circle shrinks to zero size. It is natural to think of γ as being a Euclidean black hole horizon. Given a (time-independent) metric ĝ P GR with length β̂ for the S1 factor at the cavity wall, we will define the metric Ψβrĝs via the scaling:

Figure 1. An illustration of how we organize the space of bulk metrics GR. The horizontal surfaces are codimension-1 slices of constant β. The red lines are 1-dimensional surfaces that define a notion of what it means to keep ‘the rest of the metric’ constant while changing β, and can thus be said to define additional coordinates on the space of all metrics. We may in particular proceed by choosing a reference value β̂ and lifting any coordinates Ψp1q, Ψp2q on the corresponding horizontal surface to the full space by taking them to be constant along the red lines. We use Ψβ̂rgs to denote the result of inverting this procedure by taking a general metric g and ‘projecting’ it along the red lines into the horizontal surface at β̂.
Note that since the period of τ remains 2π instead of becoming 2πβ̂{β, (2.6) does not describe a spacetime diffeomorphism associated with rescaling τ . As a result, the map Ψβ can change the local spacetime geometry at the surface γ where the τ circle shrinks to zero size. Indeed, when g is smooth the metric Ψβrĝs will have a conical singularity at γ for all β ‰ β̂. We will thus explicitly include metrics with such conical singularities3 in the space of metrics GR, though as usual, we will not attempt to specify in detail the space of metrics over which the path integral will be performed. We simply imagine that GR can be constructed as an appropriate completion of the space of smooth metrics, so that properties of the singular members of GR can be derived by taking limits of results for the smooth case.4 This is natural for the above conical geometries, and also for geometries that may involve conical singularities on other codimension-2 surfaces.
Nevertheless, the idea that metrics in the domain of integration are smooth is a convenient and familiar fiction. In order to preserve this fiction to the greatest extent

The current work is sufficiently formal that we will not concern ourselves with this issue further, though it would be good to address this in the future.
4In particular, while it is traditional to search for negative modes around saddles for the canonical ensemble by studying smooth fluctuations, treating conical singularities as limits of smooth metrics means that allowing this conical singularity to fluctuate can add nothing new.

Furthermore, by comparing with the Hamiltonian form of the gravitational action (see e.g. [27]) and noting that the usual symplectic term πij 9hij vanishes due to time-independence of the metric, we see that the bulk terms in Hrrgs are precisely the usual (Euclidean) Hamiltonian and momentum constraints for g “ Ψβrg multiplied by corresponding (Euclidean) lapse and shift and integrated over the spacetime. Note that the Euclidean lapse is complex when our T is real. Corresponding statements will also be true for more complicated theories with higher derivative corrections. In the approximation where we neglect dependence of µ on T , it is now straightforward to perform the T -integral in (2.7). The integral simply enacts a fourier transform:

In the limit σ2 Ñ 0, up to normalization the effect of the factor rfEpHq is simply to restrict the domain of integration metrics rg P GR which also satisfy Hrrgs “ E. This is the microcanonical path integral whose stability we will study in section 5, where we will find agreement with physical expectations. In summary, with our restriction to time-independent metrics and modulo footnote 5, performing the integral over T and taking σ2 Ñ 0 gives a microcanonical path integral that integrates over metrics rg P rGR with Hrrgs “ E. Much as one might naively expect, this is an integral over smooth metrics (or at least those without conical singularities at γ since rg P rGR) with fixed (off-shell) energy, but where the period of the S1 is allowed to fluctuate. Furthermore, since the integral over T was precisely the Fourier transform of a Gaussian, fluctuations in T about the saddle-point are clearly stable. We now wish to evaluate the remaining integrals using the saddle-point approximation. For Einstein-Hilbert gravity the Euclidean (AdS)-Schwarzschild solutions all give saddles, and we will see in section 5 that with cosmological constant Λ ď 0 these saddles are all stable at quadratic order. However, before embarking on explicit computations, we first provide a few further results in section 2.2 that will allow us to recast the analysis of perturbative stability as a standard search for negative modes in a Sturm-Liouville-type problem in section 3.

We wish to study saddle points that make p´Arrgs{4Gq stationary under variations δrg that preserve the constraint Hrrgs “ E, or in other words for which δH “ 0. This makes it easy to relate such saddles to stationary points rg˚ of the canonical ensemble variational problem defined by varying Irrgs “ ´A{4G ` rβHrrgs at fixed rβ. sections.heading: 3 Formulation of the stability problem
sections.text:
The strategy we will follow in studying stability of our microcanonical saddles will be essentially identical to that used for the canonical ensemble in [22]. We review this approach briefly below. Since the purpose of this section is to make contact with our later explicit calculations, we now change notation to again parallel traditional choices made in analyzing the existence of such negative modes. In particular, in this section we will write all indices explicitly and drop therover quantities associated with smooth metrics. From a conceptual point of view, the most important issue to discuss is to fix a contour of integration for the path integral. After all, given a saddle in the complex plane, at least locally one can always find a steepest descent contour along which fluctuations about the saddle would be stable. On the other hand, one can similarly always find a steepest ascent contour along which fluctuations about the same saddle would be unstable. So an investigation of stability can have meaning only if we first fix the contour of integration. Recall that a purely-real Euclidean contour is not viable (see e.g. [28]). Due to the conformal factor problem, such a choice would imply that all saddles are badly unstable. A traditional choice has been to Wick-rotate pure-trace modes [28] or some direct analogue [8] (perhaps found by following the approach of [6]) while preserving the reality of the Euclidean transverse-traceless modes. See also [29–31] in the cosmological context. But our microcanonical boundary conditions require us to fix the area of the Euclidean horizon, which will turn out to couple the pure-trace and transverse-traceless modes. It is thus impossible to Wick-rotate the former without also Wick-rotating the latter. This, however, is precisely the same issue that arises in the study of the canonical ensemble in a finite cavity [22]. We may thus use the rule-of-thumb described in that work to fix the contour of integration. Though we refer the reader to the original reference for details, the end result is determined by the spectrum of an operator L defined by first choosing an inner product on the space of perturbations hab and then combining this metric with second functional derivatives of the action. In particular, suppose we have an action Ǐ (the reason for the check (̌) will be explained shortly). Suppose also that Ǐ is a quadratic function of independent and unconstrained7 real field variables QI that is stationary at QI “ 0. If we also choose a real inner product

The operator L is always self adjoint with respect to the inner product (3.1). It is assumed to be diagonalizeable, though, since the inner product we choose will not be positive definite, the spectrum of L is generally complex. After the Wick rotation, a mode with eigenvalue λ is stable if and only if Re λ ą 0. As in [22], we use the DeWitt´1 inner product. Due to this choice, L will again be just the familiar Lichnerowicz operator in the bulk, though it will be equipped with new boundary conditions and, in addition, the operator itself will now contain an additional boundary term at the cavity wall.
To explain this point in detail, we expand a general metric gab near a saddle ĝab as

Here δIp2qB is a boundary term at the cavity wall whose detailed form can be found in the appendix A. Now, if one imposes boundary conditions appropriate to the canonical ensemble, the boundary term δIp2qB vanishes. It is possible that we might achieve a similar result in the microcanonical case by working directly with the microcanonical action. But to make contact with familiar technology, we instead use the strategy described at the end of section 2.2 that involves working with I, but also implementing appropriate microcanonical boundary conditions. Recall that these boundary conditions enforce two conditions at the Euclidean horizon: lack of a conical singularity and preservation of the horizon area. In fact, for static
– 12 –
J H E P 1 1 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 0 4 6
modes with zero angular momentum these are the only boundary conditions required to be enforced.8 In particular, for such modes there are no boundary conditions at the cavity wall. As a result, the boundary conditions are of little use in simplifying δIp2qB . This boundary term turns out to be both complicated and subtle. We find it useful to deal with such subtleties by working directly with a discretized version of the system and then numerically investigating the continuum limit. This is in accord with the general strategy described in section 2.2 of [22]. After discretizing the action and expressing the result in terms of fields not constrained by boundary conditions, it is straightforward to take derivatives of the action and then to define L via (3.2). This contrasts with the traditional approach of [2–4, 7, 9, 10, 32–34] which used the continuum action to define a continuum differential operator, after which the boundary conditions could be used to define an appropriate discretization of this operator. The one remaining issue to be discussed involves the diffeomorphism gauge symmetries. The main point here is that each such symmetry gives rise to zero-eigenvalue eigenvectors of L, making the spectrum of L highly degenerate. This is technically troublesome, so we will take steps to remove this degeneracy. Here, again, we follow the treatment of [22] and we refer the reader to that reference for details (see in particular its appendix A). In essence, we will impose the de Donder gauge condition
∇ahab ´ 1 2∇bh “ 0. (3.7)
For static spherically-symmetric perturbations about Euclidean AdS-Schwarzschild, the time-component of the de Donder gauge condition is straightforward to implement. Indeed, doing so corresponds merely to setting the τr component of the metric perturbation to zero, where r is the usual area-radius and τ is a standard Killing time coordinate on AdS-Schwarzschild. However, it is non-trivial to impose the remaining radial component. While it can also be solved, inserting the solution into the action leads to a higher-derivative action that is more complicated to study. As a result, we will not solve the radial component of the de Donder condition explicitly (though it will be convenient to impose both the condition and its derivative precisely at the cavity wall as a extra boundary conditions). Instead, we will call the quadratic gravitational action I (with no check (̌)), and we will define a new action

But when it results from discretization, this gives only a tiny splitting between the eigenvalues of L associated with would-be gauge degrees of freedom, and in particular this splitting disappears when the discretization scale is taken to zero so that the continuum limit is restored. We find it useful create a larger splitting by adding by hand an additional term that breaks gauge invariance and whose effects do not vanish in the continuum limit.

As a result, in the bulk the resulting L will just be the usual Lichnerowicz operator, or a discretized version thereof, though it is now supplemented by novel boundary terms and boundary conditions. As explained in [22], the properties of the de Donder gauge then imply that the eigenmodes of L will sort themselves nicely into modes satisfying the de Donder condition and modes that are pure gauge. With these details in hand, we are now ready to analyze our gravitational system.

sections.text:
In this work we will focus on studying the stability properties of the Euclidean Schwarzschild black hole, whose line element can be written as

Since the microcanonical path integral of section 2 was constructed from the canonical path integral by performing only a single extra integral over the zero angularmomentum mode described by T , perturbations that carry momentum on the Sd´2 sphere will satisfy the same boundary conditions as for the canonical ensemble. Furthermore, in the infinite cavity limit, adding angular momentum has been shown in [35] to increase the eigenvalues of the Lichnerowicz operator. We will assume that the corresponding result continues to hold in the presence of a finite-radius spherical wall and reserve a careful check of this assumption for future work. Since the background metric is spherically symmetric, we can use the background symmetry to decompose metric perturbations into tensor, vector and scalar derived perturbations. These are metric perturbations built from tensor, vector and scalar harmonics, respectively. Since tensor and vector harmonics necessarily carry momentum, they are excluded using our previous argument. We are thus left with a spherically symmetric scalar perturbation. Imposing the τ component of the de Donder condition (3.7) sets the τr component of the perturbation to zero, leaving us with
δds2 “ aprqfprqdτ2 ` bprq fprqdr 2 ` cprq r2dΩ2d´2 . (4.2)

As a result, we see that we in fact have five boundary conditions. This is not yet enough boundary conditions to make our problem well-posed. Perhaps more explicitly, this is not yet enough boundary conditions to allow us to define a consistent second-order differencing scheme that gives rise to a well-defined discretized version of the action. To proceed, we simply impose the de Donder gauge condition (3.7) at the cavity wall, which then provides a Robin-type boundary condition for b1pr0q. We thus have precisely six boundary conditions in total, which is the correct number to define a discretized version of a second-order action for three fields.

sections.heading: 5 Results
sections.text:
We now report the results of our numerical investigations. The action defined by combining the discussion of section 2.2 with the boundary conditions of section 4 may be discretized using the method described in [22]. Combining this with the analogously discretized DeWitt´1 metric defines an operator L via (3.2). Since the system has already been discritized, this L is just a large matrix whose eigenvalues and eigenvectors can be studied using standard numerical methods [36].
As in [22], to decrease the clutter, we define the dimensionless quantities
rλ ” λ r2` , y0 ” r0 r` , and y` ” r` ` . (5.1)
The limit of zero cosmological constant is obtained by setting y` Ñ 0. Figure 2 displays results for the lowest lying eigenmode (i.e., the mode with smallest Re λ) as a function of y0 and y` for d “ 4 (left panel) and d “ 5 (right panel). This mode turns out to be real and positive. This shows that the Euclidean Schwarzschild-AdS black hole is stable in the microcanonical ensemble, as expected. In addition to what is shown in the figure, with y` “ 0 we extended our results to y0 „ 40 and found the lowest mode to always remain real. The positive eigenvalue indicates that the mode displayed in figure 2 is stable after making the Wick rotation proposed in [22]. But, as an aside, it is interesting to ask if this particular mode is one of the ones to be Wick-rotated, or it if is to be left along the real Euclidean axis. The answer to that question is determined by studying the norm of the

We now attempt to give a more comprehensive survey of the overtones. For concreteness, we take y` “ 0, but we find similar results for y` ‰ 0. In general, the eigenvalues λ are complex, just as with canonical boundary conditions [22]. However, for the canonical boundary conditions discussed in [22], at any given y0, y` only a small number of the eigenvalues were λ complex. In contrast, when considering microcanonical boundary conditions, at least when the cavity is large enough we find almost all eigenvalues to be complex. In figure 4 we plot the first twenty overtones in d “ 4 as a function of y0 P p1, 10q for y` “ 0. The bottom row shows magnified versions of small regions from the figures in the top row. The left column shows the real part of the eigenvalue and the right column shows the corresponding imaginary part. Just as for canonical boundary conditions, we see that a negative and positive norm modes can merge to form a complex mode. Due to the approach described in section 2.2, some fraction of the modes shown in figure 4 are pure gauge. Modes are classified as gauge vs. non-gauge by comparing the modified action Šp2q to the original action Sp2q, with vanishing of the latter (to numerical precision) indicating a gauge-mode while for non-gauge modes the values agree. As a consistency check, we also verify that the non-gauge modes are precisely those that satisfy the de Donder gauge condition as expected.

Figure 4. The real part (left column) and the imaginary part (right column) of the excited modes as a function of y0 for y` “ 0. The figures in the bottom row show magnified versions of small regions from the figures in the top row. All plots are for d “ 4. The colour coding is as follows: green triangles are non-gauge modes with complex eigenvalues; blue diamonds are non-gauge modes with negative norm under Ĝ; red squares are non-gauge modes with positive norm under Ĝ and the black disks are pure gauge modes. Each green triangle has a two-fold degeneracy since complex modes come in conjugate pairs.
any complex modes becomes precisely the negative norm mode after the merger. Similarly, the real part of any complex mode becomes the corresponding positive norm mode after the merger. A similar structure can be seen in figure 5 which displays analogous results for d “ 5. Let us now generalize the discussion to y` ą 0 (i.e., to Λ ă 0). Corresponding results for the overtones in this case are shown in figure 6. There we plot the imaginary (left column) and real (right columns) of the first excited complex mode for d “ 4 (top row) and d “ 5 (bottom row). Unlike the case for the canonical boundary conditions studied in [22], we now find that the size of the interval in y0 where a given mode is complex now has only a weak dependence on y`. In particular, we find large regions of parameter space where complex modes exist even for very large black holes (as large as y` “ 10).

in writing the microcanonical partition function as an integral over the inverse temperature β of the canonical partition, and then performing this β integral before path-integrating over ‘the rest of the spacetime metric’. This procedure is not unique, but depends on what aspects of the metric are held fixed during the β-integration.
We simplify the problem by considering only metrics that preserve a Up1q Euclidean time-translation symmetry that fixed a locus we may call the Euclidean horizon. In that context, for a natural choice of what it means to ‘fix the rest of the metric’, we obtain a microcanonical path integral that specifies the value of a certain off-shell notion of the Hamiltonian that we call H. This H is defined by including terms that would be called constraints in the canonical formalism, multiplied by appropriate notions of lapse and shift. With this choice, and using the Wick-rotation specified by the rule-of-thumb from [22], we find no microcanonical negative modes in perturbation theory about any SchwarzschildAdSd black holes inside a cavity of any radius in pure Einstein-Hilbert asymptotically-AdSd gravity with Λ ď 0 for either d “ 4 or d “ 5. In particular, including the constraint terms resolves the tension mentioned in the introduction that the negative mode in the
– 20 –

asymptotically-flat canonical ensemble falls off too quickly to contribute to the usual ADM energy. We presume the corresponding solutions to give stable microcanonical saddles in other dimensions as well. While we worked with vacuum gravity, the general arguments did not depend on the detailed form of the action, so it is straightforward to extend the present formalism to include couplings to matter fields. There are, however, a number of directions that remain to be explored. First, one would like to study more interesting ensembles, such as those associated with rotating black holes. This will be the subject of future work, where we anticipate finding that their study is facilitated by using the Hamiltonian form of the path integral. Indeed, as indicated in footnote 5, the Hamiltonian formalism will also give better control over issues related to the path integral measure. We also expect the Hamiltonian formalism to allow the inclusion of modes that break the Euclidean time-translation symmetry, in which case we expect the corresponding method to fix a time-averaged notion of off-shell energy. This then raises the question of studying negative modes in the Hamiltonian framework, where off-shell modes can involve fluctuations of canonical momenta that are not determined by time-derivatives of the spatial metric. To our knowledge, this problem has not yet been studied in the literature.
– 21 –
J H E P 1 1 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 0 4 6
Another important open question involves the choice of what it means to integrate over β while holding the rest of the spacetime metric fixed. Here we studied a particular simple and perhaps natural such definition, and it is this choice that led to our particular definition of the off-shell Hamiltonian H. Other choices will lead to microcanonical path integrals that fix some different notion of off-shell Hamiltonian, and which may thus appear on the surface to give different results. This may be a particular concern due to the fact that our definition explicitly breaks diffeomorphism-invariance, and that it seems likely that any other definition will as well.
It should thus be checked that the final physics is invariant under diffeomorphisms, and in particular that it is independent of the particular way in which this choice is made. As noted in the main text, this is to be expected since, at some level, changing this choice just corresponds to performing the required integrals in a different order. On the other hand, we also noted that the microcanonical path integral (2.3) integrates over a contour on which metrics cannot be real, and that specifying precisely what is meant by allowing the period β “ β0 ` iT to be complex ‘without deforming the contour for the other variables of integration variables’ requires us to make some such choice. Thus the expectation that predictions of the ensemble will not depend on this choice relies on assuming that the contour can be deformed without changing the partition function. While this seems entirely plausible, verifying that it is the case should be a high priority.
We should also mention that there are cases where we do expect negative modes in the microcanonical path integral. In particular, we expect these to occur whenever the background solution is classically unstable. One such example occurs when we consider embedding the Euclidean Schwarzschild-AdS5 in IIB supergravity with AdS5ˆS5 asymptotics via the standard Freud-Rubin compactifications [37]. At small energies the usual Schwarzschild-AdS5 black hole becomes dynamically unstable [4, 38–45] to the Gregory-Laflamme instability [46]. The endpoint of this instability has been argued to be a ten-dimensional localised black hole, which has been constructed in [44] and also admits a regular Euclidean section.
This onset of the above instability signals the existence of a zero-mode for the associated Euclidean section. Fixing the energy thus defines a mode that gives a zero-eigenvalue in the matrix of 2nd derivatives of the horizon area. We expect this eigenvalue to become negative after the onset of the instability.10 However, to study this phenomenon in detail, one must resort to analysing fluctuations of the Euclidean Schwarzschild-AdSˆS5 in type IIB supergravity. This is a formidable task that we leave for future endeavours.
Finally, while the results of our Euclidean analysis seem quite satisfactory, as usual in Euclidean gravity it remains to better understand the proper treatment of the conformal mode. In particular, while the rule of thumb proposed in section 3 seems likely to generalize to a wide array of systems, it makes use of both the de Donder gauge and the interpretation of Ĝ as a metric on the space of perturbations. Yet there is no clear reason why either of
10Indeed, in Lorentz signature ref. And under the expectation that kinetic energy is positive, it is enough to check time-independent perturbations in which we can interpret this A as the area of an extremal suface (and which we can also Wick-rotated to Euclidean signature).

J H E P 1 1 ( 2 0 2 2 ) 0 4 6
these structures should be physically preferred. One should thus investigate further the extent to which the results depend on these choices or, even better, to find a first-principles derivation of the correct recipe. In accord with previous suggestions from [5, 47–54], we expect the Lorentz-signature path integral to provide a useful starting point for such an analysis since, as an oscillatory integral, it should be well-defined in a distribution sense without any Wick rotation. Allowed deformations of the contour of integration for this path integral might then be used to define the correct Euclidean prescription. We hope to at least partially address this issue in future work.
